captions.text:
Derby Day on Wednesday June the fourth, 1913.
And as the highest and the lowest in the land

converged on Epsom Downs, this year there
was a particular buzz in the air, not to mention

a great deal of extra security, because the
King, George the Fifth, had a fancied runner

- a horse called Anmer, which was a strong
ante-post favourite.

Bt as the Royal party arrived to see the race,
there was another, more desperate sub-plot

running through the meeting, known to just
a handful of people. A demonstration was going

to be made on behalf of the suffragette movement.
This was an increasingly violent campaign

by women demanding the right to vote in political
elections. Hunger strikes, bomb attacks, marches

and meetings, had all been used in the years
beforehand to press the women's claims. But

what was to happen today, was to place the
suffragette cause onto quite another level

of public consciousness.
Just as the field was rounding Tattenham Corner,

a young woman stepped out from behind the
rails, waited for Anmer to come by, and as

it did, to the horror of the crowd, she grabbed
at the horse's reins, bringing it down. Emily

Davison was the young woman's name. She was
critically injured.

Slowed down, it's plain to see just how coolly
Miss regaining consciousness. Horse and jockey

both recovered.
Miss Davison's funeral brought thousands of

suffragettes and their supporters onto the
streets. There were wreaths from all over

the world. A guard of honour was provided
by women wearing white dresses and black sashes,

the symbol of the woman's suffragette movement.
Women got the vote five years later. That

they did so, was in no small measure due to
Emily Davison's brave sacrifice on Derby Day,

title: Emily Davison Throws Herself Under The Kings Horse (1913)
